title: Several crashes with ethereum/client-go:v1.9.24 container
body:
This is a fresh install running on an Intel NUC 10th generation. Here is the relevant part of my docker-compose:

```
  geth:
    image: ethereum/client-go:v1.9.24
    restart: always
    ports:
      - 30303:30303/tcp
      - 30303:30303/udp
    volumes:
      - ./data/geth:/root/.ethereum
      - /etc/timezone:/etc/timezone:ro
      - /etc/localtime:/etc/localtime:ro
    command: --nousb --http --http.addr=0.0.0.0 --http.port=8545 --http.vhosts="*" --http.corsdomain="*" --http.api="eth,net"
```

#### System information

Geth version: `1.9.24`
OS & Version: Ubuntu 20.x

#### Expected behaviour
Perform full sync on mainnet

#### Actual behaviour
Crashes with:
1.
```
fatal error: unexpected signal during runtime execution

[signal SIGSEGV: segmentation violation code=0x80 addr=0x0 pc=0x423050]
```

or

2.
```
unexpected fault address 0x0

fatal error: fault

[signal SIGSEGV: segmentation violation code=0x80 addr=0x0 pc=0xc9c502]
```

or

3. 
```
panic: leveldb: internal key xxx corrupted: invalid type
```


#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
Just start a full sync.

#### Backtrace

Attached the (big) log of that container. Several geth restarts and crashes. I understand that the db got corrupted, but the question is why and how to avoid it :)

[geth-docker-crashlogs.txt](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/files/5625495/geth-docker-crashlogs.txt)

Adding the chaindata db log file if it helps:
[004714.log](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/files/5625519/004714.log)

According to [stefa2k](https://github.com/stefa2k) this might be related to:
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-28928

Exact version: `Geth/v1.9.24-stable-cc05b050/linux-amd64/go1.15.5`


First crash:

Yes.. I think the first one is the most interesting -- after leveldb has an internal panic, all bets are off, and the db can be in some very odd state where it keeps panicing due to some internal corruption. Leveldb hasn't changed much recently, so it's odd that this has started happening, but we have had a few tickets related to this recently, so definitely something we need to investigate.

The last one that you reported -- `unexpected fault address 0x0` -- that one actually comes from a separate database, `./ethereum/geth/nodes`, which is a database of nodes, and is much smaller than the 'regular' one. It might be small enough to share, and we could try to dissect it a bit and see if we can figure out the corruption?

That database seems fine, when I open it locally. It has `18647` entries,


In either case, the disk db seems intact, so I'm starting to wonder if there might be some issue with your memory modules. Could you run some RAM-check tool?

Spot on. Ran memtest and there were tons of errors...
